title: a better rule for not using bag of features
body:
this is in 2 parts

1. take figure 2 of this: https://econpapers.repec.org/scripts/redir.pf?u=https%3A%2F%2Fosf.io%2Fdownload%2F5f344aad8e0d46001abe7014%2F;h=repec:osf:osfxxx:ek4n3

now, add another row, which includes 4 more graphs, each of which has 1-2 edges different from the above, but *totally* different #triangles and GCC.  

The points are: 
1. knowing the set of features doesn't characterize the graph well, and
2. These features are not robust to noisy estimates of the edges


There is a third point then which has to do with causal mechanisms/explanations:

3. It is conceptually impossible to do a causal analysis on whether the identified feature is causally involved in the capacity we are discussing. Consider doing a 'knock-in' and 'knock-out' experiment, or another form of a positive and negative control.  It is conceptually not even possible.  We cannot change just one graph statistic, without altering essentially all of the others.  This is why we need parametric models, where parameters can be manipulated independently of one another (such as the mean and variance).
